I use a trackpad on a Mac. One of the tutorial instructions (5/11) says 'click the mouse wheel to do X.' Well, guess what, I have no mouse wheel and although I can scroll up and down I can't click a non-existent mouse wheel. There is no obvious way to remap this function, as the tutorial doesn't give the name and no option says 'click mouse wheel' in its setting. What a horrible user interface. I couldn't even get five minutes into the game before giving up. Huge waste of money. Steam should really give a refund and say 'game requires 3-button mouse with clickable scroll wheel and will not function with a trackpad' in bold, red letters on the store page.  On top of the aforementioned, I kept playing with the control options. Guess what? The arrow keys don't work to scroll the screen around, at least not on this Mac playing in windowed mode. The developers really should be ashamed.  Finally, as if that wasn't enough... I can't quit Steam after quitting the game. It's not running - it's not in the window list, the dock, Activity Monitor or even 'ps.' However, Steam thinks it's running, so I have to FORCE QUIT Steam, which has all sorts of negative effects (like not syncing any saved games). This really is a top shelf piece of junk.

I really wanted to love this game. But after playing several hours I'm mostly just frustrated. Reasons why below.  Pros - Beautiful atmosphere and graphics - Fun resource management  Cons - Lack of proper tutorial mission or integrated tutorial messages. Instead they rain text boxes down on you. Game is quite complicated, so it left me feeling confused. - On easy mode I'm getting slaughtered. I usually consider myself pretty good at games, but it feels like the dungeons are quite unbalanced. Sometimes I make it several levels, other times I can't make it past the first (setup with an impossible scenario). Easy mode probably shouldn't fluctuate the difficulty so much. This is something I would expect on medium or hard. - Frustrating that I have to take a hero with me 3 levels or beat the entire dungeon to keep them. Makes me feel like I'm not making any progress whenever I die. Wish I could just save and collect them. - Mini modules feel a little odd and somewhat unbalanced. - Wish user select menu told me more about character roles and their abilities.

A really cool rogue like tower defense game. A really different concept, and pulled together very well. It is a lot of fun, BUT you cannot save in multiplayer. When you start getting into later levels each level takes quite a bit of time to complete which would be fine EXCEPT the fact that the game randomly disconnects other players oh and did I mention you can't save your game.. It is very frusterating when you play a game for 3+ hours to end up getting a disconnect and the player cannot rejoin they are just out.. Saving even if it was just at the beginning of the level would resolve this.  Honestly I do not want to play this game in any other mode then multiplayer and it is a great multiplayer experience outside of what I mentioned above. It is fairly well polished, and picking up multiplayer games and joining with your friends is easy and well done. Devs please if you are reading this add multiplayer saves, even if its just a char save at the beginning of the level.   Rating 7.5/10 - Most of the game feels very polished, and plays well. If the multiplayer saves weren't an issue I would probably rate it at a 9.5/10 or 10/10 but it is infuriating when you get disconnected after 3 hours of play.

A satisfying Rogue-lite that is heavier on careful planning than reaction speed. Dungeon of the Endless mixes elements of RPGs with tower defense and dungeon crawlers to create a surprisingly deep strategic experience. The randomized floors and unlockable hero characters give it great replay value, and the chance to mix rules with different starting setups make this a good time sink. The game features a resource management system that forces you to think about your choices: 'should I construct more turrets to make sure I survive this next wave, or can I save some construction points for the more difficult stages later?' is something you have to ask yourself constantly. And as with almost all Rogue-lite games, the Dungeon features permadeath of characters. Mixing permadeath with healing supplies consuming the same resources as leveling up can cause some stress as you must make the choice between securing a team member's life and giving them a vital level up that'd make them stronger later on. Overall, Dungeon of the Endless has thus far impressed me with it's versitility and highly apparent replay value. It has already been worth it's price, and I'm fairly confident I'm going to be spending even more time with this challenge of risk and reward.

Dungeon of the Endless is extremely fun and extremely addictive and provides a unique and difficult style of gameplay, being a cross between tower defence, gauntlet, rpg and capture the flag.   You may find yourself dying the first 5 times you play but thats all part of the learning process, also you may have just been unlucky and had a large dungeon generated for you... that can happen.  You will need to think about what you are doing with each room you enter, you need to work out what defences you will place and what route will be the most viable for your heroes and on top of all that you need to manage your recources wisely.  It's addictive and challenging so i strongly reccomend getting this game.

Very well made mashup of rogue-like and tower defense.  Minimalist story told mostly through character backgrounds and some between floor dialog when the right combination of characters are in the room together.  Standard difficulty (called 'Easy') is fairly difficult for me, easier difficulty (called 'Too Easy') is probably a little too easy.  After completing the game once, different modes will be unlocked that add replayability. For example, an 'Armory' where you start with 4 armed characters, but cannot produce any tower defense-style 'turrets'. Or an 'Infirmary' where you have access to additonal drug items.  Characters are unlocked through play, and while characters don't seem significantly different from others in the same class, they are still unique enough for me to get excited when I encounter a new character in the dungeon. While no character has an offical class-type to link to other characters, I generally class them as 'fighter' 'operator' 'scout', etc.  The game has a pause function for tactical decisions in single player. In multiplayer, no pause is available.  Overall, I really recommend it. It is not often that I play something that feels NEW to me, but this game really does not feel derivative or evolutionary. It seems like something quite fresh and unique!

Alright where to start. This is gonna be a casual review. DOTE(Dungeon of the Endless, Duh)is a pretty fun yet brutal game. Each game is new, the floor plans being random, items random, the merch random. . .you get the point. Due to this it's a fresh start everytime! There are many characters for you to find as you progress your tour of the site. Leveling up is fun, but hard to those not prepared as the game progresses which leads me to the brutal part. It is one of the many careless early on mistakes one makes. The resources you spend in the beginning of the game will be well how to say it. . .very much missed. While you can get them back now easily, depending on how you alloct spending, higher levels means harder bosses. More resources are needed. Spent all resources on last floor. Is being swarmed by endless wave of foes and is about die/lose crystal. Being prepared is key becuase if you ♥♥♥♥ up, it's back to floor one. Though even through all of that, the game is fun, addiciting, and leaves me coming back for more! Awesome music, great story behind the characters, super pixel art work. It's just fantastic overall!  However. . .  While what I am about to say isn't the games fault entirely, but partly, is the Multiplayer. Now the multiplayer is fun. . .if certain conditions are met. The mp can glitch. For me the only game breaking glitch I've found is if the host, swaps through ships too quickly, it'll cause the interface to crash. If you leave the game, the character selection will still be there. Moving through different menus will eventally break the interface, forcing one to restart. Now, this is a rare issue since many people know not to do it expect noobies. My second, and by far biggest issue which is turning me off greatly, are the hosts. What you do mean you may ask? One word: Autokick. I seriously can say that 90% of all games joined, autokicked. This is partly do to that: A. The host has friends he or she wants to join in so they can go on and play or, B. The host, is just a troll and ♥♥♥♥ in general and has too much damn time on their hands. I'd like to see an option to host private games in the future, becuase really, while I can start a match sure, joining a game shouldn't feel like Russian Roulette expect here there are 5 bullets in the chamber.   Really other than that, DOTE is a pretty fun and challenging game and recommend it. 9/10

This is a unique blend of tower defense and dungeon delving with some light (primarily permanent death) rogue-like elements sprinkled on top. My only gripe is that the game is in real-time as this is the perfect structure for an excellent and strategic turn-based game. As it stands, the combat is, in some ways, the weakest part of the game as you have very little control over your characters and turrets. Yes, you can move your characters around and use special abilities, but targeting and crowd control remain a bit of an issue due to the unnecessarily chaotic combat.   Other than that, I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys tower defense style games with a twist so long as they aren't allergic to antiquated graphics.

Dungeon of the endless is a mix of quite a few genres, including rogue-like and tower defense. You start the game crashing into a planet after your ship was shot down by a nearby planets defenses. You will have the choice of 4 characters in the beginning, but you can unlock many other unique characters by finding them, buying them, and playing 3 floors with them or beating the game. Once you have picked your characters you will spawn in your crashed escape pod (which you can unlock more by doing certain things) and you will open the door into the dungeon, and likely into certain death. Whenever you open a door it has a chance to spawn monsters in that room, or in any other room that is unlit. You can light rooms by using the dust you get from killing monsters and opening rooms, hitting your middle-mouse button on the room you want, will light or unlight it depending on which it was before. Dust is probably one of the most important resources, among industry, science, food, and weapons and armor and tools that you equip on your characters. You will use your industry to build defenses, your science to improve the things that you can place and build with industry, and food will allow you to upgrade your characters, heal them, and pay for characters in the dungeon to join your quest to escape this hell hole of a dungeon. This game is also multi-player allowing you to get a group of your friends and conquer the dungeon as a group. Whether playing with friends or alone this game has many different escape pods (which change up settings in the game making it easier and harder), characters (up to around 20 I believe with the DLC's), and with the levels always different and the items being random, you can either get screwed or be the luckiest man on earth. But what makes this game good is that even if you get screwed in the beginning with good setup of your defenses and wise use of you characters and abilities, you can pull through and win.  I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a mix of luck, tower defense and the planning aspect of that, and the constant fear of the perma death from rogue-likes.

Dungeon of the Endless is a great Rogue-Like strategy game that makes heavy use of the random number generator (though skill and tactics are still vital to success). You control a crew of misfit space adventurers as they attempt to reach the surface of a strange alien dungeon after crashing their ship deep into its core. The game involves resource management, defense placement, hero and gear advancement, and research. Each of your heroes gains unique abilities and skills that determine how they perform, which greatly affects your overall approach to strategy and gameplay. You'll probably die a lot, but doing so is part of what makes this Rogue-Like game so much fun.  What I Liked:    Large assortment of potential characters to build your crew    Random dungeon layouts and events allow for amazing replayability    Hero interaction differs according to team composition (banter, unique events, etc.)    Different gameplay modes via ship selection change the rules of the game in interesting ways    Addictive 'just-one-more-level' style of gameplay   What I Disliked:    Pixel graphics are okay, but I'd prefer if the game had more advanced graphics     Equipment selection for your heroes is not extensive, and items tend to repeat throughout the game   Overall Rating: A (one of my favorite games)

After many years, I think maybe this is finally the roguelike for me. Manages to both appeal to my strategic turn-based urges (with its door-opening advancement mechanic) *and* scratch that real-time fighting itch (as everything busts loose after opening the next door). Manages to have just enough resource-and-defense management to be fun as a tower-defense type game but also has just enough character-advancement-and-development to feel like something of an RPG. After about a dozen failed games (including a couple of almost-victories) I got out with a thorough enough victory to unlock almost all of the other pods simultaneously, and now it's just freewheeling terror-fun - sometimes playing slowly and cautiously, building out level by level with brutally effective strategic defenses, other times playing fast and furious by focusing on jamming up the heroes' power levels and just winging the fights as they come. And sometimes it works perfectly while other times... well, let's just say that when things go wrong, they go completely wrong very fast.  Also, I have never once used the pause key deliberately, only ever bumped it by accident. You should adopt the same policy.

I got this game during Early Access, and while it was an entertaining romp, I quickly moved on to other games. I would not draw the comparison to FTL lightly, as that is one of my favorite games, but I have no choice when Dungeon of the Endless is that good.  Waves of enemies constantly threaten your ragtag team of prisoners, natives and/or lawmen. Careful management of resources to level your team or build defenses or buy items is crucial. Procedurally generated levels make sure you don't get bored. Subplots and secret characters await discovery. There is a lot of be had, here.  Just buy the game. You won't regret it. Dungeon of the Endless is all about the joys of random loot and exploration of an interesting universe. The music, atmosphere, and pixel art is all spot on (just don't look at the awful pixel portraits). The game also boasts a very pretty, albeit underused art style through an album of drawn out depictions of enemies, ships, and characters.  The characters themselves deserve a special mention, because each one has their own distinct charm and play. This is even further explored in that characters interact with one another in interesting ways, and even provide actual game altering effects to incentivize team experimentation and boosts the game's replayability.  As for the meat of game, you start by choosing a pod (game modifier) to crash land in and the characters to bring along in it. Gameplay then revolves around opening doors. No really, opening doors is integral to the experience and the way the game functions, serving as a sort of 'turn' for generating resources, refreshing ability cooldowns, and sometimes spawning monsters. Most importantly though, it's why the game is so fun and absolutely absorbing. You see behind each door could be anything, maybe it's a really cool item, maybe it's a new hero, maybe it's even the shape and size of the room you discover that makes you shout with excitement, but whatever it is, it's what it COULD be that keeps you trekking through each floor, and ultimately what keeps you interested for so long.

Dungeon of the Endless is a randomly generated pixel dungeon crawler, featuring awesome playable characters, the highest level of replayability, and a unique leveling system. I purchased this game to enjoy co-op with a friend, and multiplayer appears to have been shoved in as a half-baked implementation.  Problems with multiplayer: - If you only have 1 hero, you will break your Operate bonus if you go to interact with any level features, like shops, new heroes, research crystals, etc.  - You can't trade or give picked up items to other players, except by selling / buying to a merchant, which ends up costing your friend the full price of the item - If a player loses their only hero, you can't transfer control of an extra one to them, so the run is over - Finally, and most glaring... you are unable to save in multiplayer. This means any runs you do have to be done in one full run, which could take hours.   On a different note, a lot of the abilities and skill descriptions are worded in the most confusing possible way, which will leave you wondering what they mean. They read like a cut and paste from Google translate.   Items in shops often grant a specific passive bonus, but don't explain what the passive bonus actually does, which is frustrating when you are new, since you'll have to look it up in a wiki or something.  Finally, some of the rules are not easy to understand. In our latest run, we opened a door and enemies spawned like normal, then suddenly all of the doors on the level opened, and more enemies spawned. It was as if we had picked up the crystal, but we had not, we had only opened a door. Why did that happen? No idea, the game provided no indication.  It is fun in the few hours I've played. The core game offers a lot of strategic and resource management decisions that must be made. I mainly wish that the co-op was properly implemented. It is deceiving to say that co-op is in when it has gamebreaking deficiences like being unable to save progress and continue later.

**Spoilers somewhat**    This Game is very fun to play and enjoyable. At the start I found it challenging with all the heroes to unlock and a lack of understanding of the game mechanics. Then slowly developing and understanding about the game mechanically and finding the games hits of hiding gems here and there with the interaction the heroes have among themselves finding that there is also a story hidden in all the carnage of the waves of monsters along with the Album. The items also provide another level of depth in the game. A feeling if you do not open all the doors you might not make it and kill yourself in the process looking for that one item that could help you in the long run to win or get that last 2 Science to get a mod that you feel is highly important. In this it makes a wonderful Strategy game that rewards risk but at the same time will simply end your game if you take a too big of bite. The different ships are also adding another level to the game providing you to change your strategy to win the game increasing its longevity over all. The developers are also active in the game development with a strong connection to their fan base using GAMES2GETHER. What to build and when? Who to place where? Do I open another door? That is the questions that you will be asking yourself all along as you play Dungeon of the Endless.

I just feel the game could give the player a lot more information which would help him progress: - No idear what the level of the monsters are, you don't really have any way to estimate the damage the monsters are going to do until they hit you... often you get the what is that damage without any way of anticipating it (and no I am not speaking about the stacking of monsters) - how does wit work? what does 2.5 wit do? 1 more ? 2 more 5 more? the return of ressources depending on wit is actually really strange and not totaly linear, still havent figured it out acutally... - How does defense work? I don't have the feeling that it is scaling nicely but again you don't see the level and not the damage of the monsters so i have no idear but from experience regen is often a lot more usefull than defense. - no way to see the lvl of your minor modules well unless perhaps on the coloartion of the pixels... some modules scales with research and some other not.. really strange again - why have the DPS stat on heroes but not on modules? - Does tear gas debuff stack? - Does the slow debuff stack? - Worst tooltips every... hp regen =>tooltip : the regenration of hp. really wouldn't have guessed this so 20 regen does mean 20hp per min, or perhaps 20 min between hp regens?.... defense tooltip: the defensiv capability of your hero... really? are you shure that this is not the damage he/here does? give me something usefull like 30% reudction of damage or absorb x damage per atack etc. - if you have fraction of ressources (which you have) then please display it.. not so hard... - Vendor is selling an item which gives me the capacity 'me first' yeah great but what dies 'me first' do?  This all are liitle details but the summe of all this just give the impression that the game isn't really finished and that they just stoped the dev at some point. Especially wen you see that they have integrated an album with pictures so you have something to look at but no explanation of how the stats work.... no combat text to show damages etc....  and then there is the hughe influence of random in the game... - The reasearch random stuff is just a pain, like wen you just don't get the 'best pal' for ages... yeah great i just start again... - The layout of the floors actually have a hughe influence on the game, some level 1 floors are acutally a lot harder than the level 2 or 3 ones just beacause of that, and then there is also the modules slots especially like wen you have the rooms around your starting point without any module slots which happens.... - the whole hero may be there or not well you will se and if not well start again... great... especially that the heros are not really balanced... - no 'door knockers' and sundely 3 of them in the same wave.... yeah good luck with that  besides all those stuff there are 4 points i really miss: - there is no sens of progress, once you have done the floor you start again whith a floor that is completly similiar to the one you just did... he may even be easyser than the one you just did.. the only difference is the level of your heros and the floor indicator on the botom right... - the dificulty differnce between 'too easy' and 'easy' if hughe and i mean after finishing the 'too easy' a couple of time i wasn't capable of finish the first couple of floors on easy... I am not saying that 'easy' is to hard i am just saying that I would have loved a 'realy easy' dificulty in the middle of the other 2. - you have to send someone to the artifact for reasearch? reall? even if there are no more monsters alive? So you send a hero from one side of the floor to the other, you wait.... you click your research, you send him back to the other side of the floor, you wait again..... In some floors it took my hero (with 30-40 speed) like 30s to make that run.... and ofc 30s back... - Once you minmize the game the mouse is not longer contained by the boundry of the game and the mouse just goins on onto my other screen.. only way to fix it quit the game and restart....  so to sumerace nice idear, hope a 2 is coming out which is more finished but for a game which cost a decend about of money way underwelming...

Great game. Has received a lot of updates and some cheap dlc for new heroes to take into the dungeon. Multiplayer is servicable if you know who you're playing with, but overall a better single player game.

The single player is really fun, and the replayability honestly never goes away. You can always make the game harder by choosing a different escape pod, so you'll never get stuck in a rut by discovering a really good strategy. Multiplayer is a little buggy and hard to control. It's still fun though.
This game is  super  fun! If you like figuring stuff out and digging around for the best solution, this is for you!

A great game to play along with friends. The strategy behind each level allows for very different playstyles and moods maintaining a certain degree of novelty for longer. It can get a little repetitive, but the different play modes and hero skills counter that for the most part.  So, overall, a very fun game to play with friends

25hrs played for first 'win' on Too Easy Difficulty. And that makes this game a MUST BUY.  This is not Dark Souls, or really even an RPG. Its like chess, with RNG, which is strangely very intense and cool.  A couple points to clear up possible misconceptions on gameplay. - You have minimal control over your character. You can move them to a room and use their 'ultimate' abilities, but mostly they stand there and do what they do (attack, operate resource generators, etc.) - Each 'turn' starts when a door is opened, and causes monsters to spawn (possibly) in any unpowered or unoccupied rooms. So opening two doors at once results in twice as many monsters (again possibly). - Hoarding resources for the later levels is critical. Dont just get enough food/science/industry to clear the floor, plan to take lots with you into the higher floors because stuff gets expensive.  I can see how this type of game would not be fun for everyone but if what you have seen about it so far makes you think about playing, just go ahead and buy it. Im pretty sure you won't be disappointed.  10/10 would leave Hikensha abandoned in a dark room surrounded by monsters as I rush for the exit again.

It is 2:30a.m here and I have finally finished the escape pod after 76 hours playtime. What a journey. I can honestly say Dungeon of Endless has captivated me like no game before it.   Amplitude have crafted a devilish game here that may turn you off initially but if you persevere or like a challenge it is just fantastic. I received DOE in a humble bundle and made a big mistake right off the bat. Do not complete the tutorial drunk! I had no idea what was going on when I tried to get back into it a few days later O.o I wish that was a good excuse for why it took me 67 attempts just to finish this game one time.   The dev plays to those people who are stubborn, like a challenge or are just straight up masochistic. You only have two choices of difficulty: Easy or very easy. I don't think I could live wih myself if I played through a game on very easy for the past 10 years. This game had me considering it just to try to get a complete playthrough.  There appears to be huge replayability as you can start with different ships that have different rulesets for the game. It has a small amount of roguelike gameplay. Enemies change slightly and dungeon layout is random. Each character has a different skillset and I found myself planning my next run throughout the day.  There is so much more to say. i don't think this game is for everyone. But if you are the type of person who had to finish super ghouls n' ghosts jump on board. Thank you Amplitude! I can finally have my life back.

This game, Dungeons of the Endless™, is an interesting take on the Sci-Fi RTS (Realtime Strategy) genre. There many things I could go into about what makes it good, what makes it bad, and the just straight-up funny stuff. But I'm partially biased because of my adoration toward RTS games, so I'll keep it simple and say this. Dungeon of the Endless™ is the kind of game that will make you rage at points and if you find yourself to be the kind of person who doesn't like RTS games and is trying to get into them, this can be considered one of the deterants. But if you love RTS or just love having a challenge, then this is the kind of game that you may like. Yes, it can get repetative. Yes, it has really subtle underlying jokes some may not get. But I thought it was good enough to get a thumbs up on Steam.

Fell in love with the gamplay after a few rounds. Nice mix of the tower defense, RTS , rogue-like genre I wish there were more people playing this game though. It shines when you play with others, teamwork is required as the difficulty increases with more players.   8/10

A delightfully small rogue-like dungeon crawler with a sprinkling of tower defense. The art style is nice and simple adding a delgihtful charm to the whole game and has enough going on to make sure you're never in complete control of a situation. The game does a good job at ramping up the difficulty and keeping you on your toes, as you may have cleared one level of the dungeon with relative ease, but suddenly things are out of control and half of your team have died upon the next level. Resource managment is the main part of the game, deciding to choose where to allocate your resources, whether it be on leveling up your characters, buying new equipment for them, making some form of defense or augment for your tower defense grid or even just building machines to give you more resources to work with. This does open the game up to a nice variety of play throughs as you can choose to rely upon just your characters to fight off the waves of enemies that spawn, or maybe take more of a focus on setting up turrets and slow fields. It's ultimately turn based and the room mechanics work pretty well as you also have to choose which rooms you actually want to light, as lit rooms don't spawn monsters to come and chew your face off. Overall I'd say it's a delightful and fun rogue-like that kept me going for a fair bit of time, and with different types of ships to really change up the game play there's always more to go back to. It's cheap, it's cheerful, you'll be stressed beyond relief at later levels as things don't go your way. Things never go your way. (More thoughts  here  [mozillogames.tumblr.com] )

One of the better rogue like games i've ever played. Tower defense like dungeon crawler strategy rescource management game... So many different aspects jammed into one game and it does all of them well.
Fantastic. I haven't been as engrossed in a strategy game in years.
An amazing game, easy to start playing hard to stop. theres multiplayer so can play with freinds, although for some reason none plays multiplayer.
After a few blood sacrifices and signing our lives away to the devs of this game, three of my friends and I finally won. Tip: After floor 8, just run when you find the door... it's better this way.

There's a lady who thinks she's a spider.   Needless to say that's enough praise but this game has never made me shout 'nooooooooo' so much in my life. Tower defence, rogue elements, rpg elements, multiple awesome characters....and bloody millions of bloody aliens that bloody spawn when you open bloody doors. They'll eat the face off your characters, use your nice new modules as butt loofahs and bash your crystal until you're in the bloody dark and pausing every half second to feverishly think of some way to not bloody die. Soon you're screaming and ripping your own eyelids off as your team gets mashed into smooth pate.  10/10 would eyelid rip again.

Fun game, Lots of gameplay, Randomly generated means levels can be way too easy or rediculousely hard, And considering that later levels get longer and larger in size, That can be a problem. But hey, you don't need to pay the price of the game, or even any money at all in order to get the soundtrack, as it's free! And the soundtrack is pretty nice. Don't know about multiplayer, as I haven't tried, but getting all the way through the dungeon in order to get a new ship seems kind of exessive.
An excellent game with surprisingly low popularity.

Ok game. Pretty poor tutorial mode. I get that the resocurces are built but what is dust? Why can't I power that room. How much dust could it possibly cost?  Edit: After reading around and learning the game from other websites, I can easily say that it is much more enjoyable. If you want to play this game, it might take some resesarch to learn all the mechanics but in the end, it is worth the effort.

I was a bit skeptical about this game because it wasn't clear how combat worked (I don't like anything with twitch gameplay). I was very pleased to find out combat is essentially exactly like FTL. If I was going to hazard a guess, the developers got a lot of inspiration from FTL because this game has a lot of the same ingredients that makes FTL great fun.  This game is awesome. I bought it during the summer sale and spent all day playing. I haven't ventured off of the easiest mode yet but I am enjoying it greatly. The characters are really neat, love the unlocks, going to upgrade to crystal edition now, not knowing what that means because I want to give the devs more money.
If you like FTL, Bloons Tower Defense, and ripping your hair out, boy are you in for a treat. 10/10
Probably my favorite game on Steam. It has endless (hue hue hue) replayability. Go for it.

Amazing game with interesting mechanics and art.  The difficulty scale never fails to impress. Finish 7 level easy peasy, dies in the 8th second room.  If you like original turn based gameplay this game is a must buy.
Good game, no community.

There are 'very easy' and 'easy' levels. Couldn't finish the game on 'easy' even once, and I'm alright. Game is addictive and very hard. Loads fast, plays fast. 'Drill pod' mission even on 'very easy' is soooo difficult. The game is nuts, loving it. But it's difficulty is frustrating. Started playing it cause I broke my hand, easy played with one.

Intensely difficult, and incredibly fun, this gorgeous gem of a game is a brilliant combination of dungeon crawling, tower defense, roguelike uncertainy and resource management. If those buzzwords sound like they tickle your fancy... pick this up, you won't regret it!

Dungeon of the Endless is a randomly generated pixel dungeon crawler, featuring awesome playable characters, the highest level of replayability, and a unique leveling system. You can place traps to fend off the monsters that exist for the sole purpose of demolishing your fun times. As you go deeper, the amount of monsters increases, and the amount of dust used to fuel the light that keeps monsters at bay decreases. This game is so completely awesome, and I totally suggest you check it out.

Although sometimes it feels impossible to win I still liked it enough to keep trying. A mostly roguelike game that is worth it for $10 or less. Multiplayer is nonexistent unless you bring the friends.

This was just supposed to be an interesting game that stayed on my wishlist and I never thought twice about. Then one Steam Sale it was purchased for me as a gift, and I was blown away by how much I liked the game. I've sunk more hours into this game than just about any other game in my library, and I always come back for more.

A game that haunts the brain. Everything in there is made with love - music, art style, gameplay, action, you need to think about good strategies, dependent on the characters you get during the game, to get through each level. Definitly worth buying if you love challenging games with simple controls and a beautiful world in which it's easy to dive into.

Starting to talk about Dungeon of The Endless, we have a perhaps unique dynamic gameplay in general, involving tower defense aspects and the essence of a good roguelike. In the game from beginning the search for differentiated strategies and new characters becomes an issue that is practiced all the time, the difficulty that the game provides and the types of unusual characters you get to know better during the game is amazing. Online multiplayer on the other hand, it's confusing, because different of solo play, seems unnecessary, because it ends up messing up the game in many ways, it's still a good way to meet people, share experiences in the game and also have fun.
like a great blend of Dungeons and Dragons and Faster Than Light

A great rogue-like game, with plenty of challenge and no 'hand holding'. Great to play with friends or alone and always challenging. The different types of game modes (escape pods) you can pick add a different flavor to the game. It's always fun to spend hours with friends trying to survive with your characters till the end.

Your spaceship crashed on a planet and went deep underground! Will you be able to get back to the surface with a ragtag team of officers and prisoners, human-eater and bug-eater, traitors and wannabe smartasses? This game is built around a turn-by-turn system where everytime you open a door to a new room events occur and resources are given. Fighting events are real-time with an active pause possible. It is a strategy game because you need to plan your usage of resources and you can place offensive/defensive/support modules like a tower defense game - but also a tactical game as you can equip your team, recruit new people and each character has different stats and abilities. A great game overall, as you also get several ships you can crash with which offer different types of gameplay (play with only 1 overpowered character, get more science resources but all characters are weakened, characters cannot be healed, and the infamous Sanitary pod where you cannot pause ever and most events are bad!)

I would absolutely recommend this game. Dungeon of the Endless satisfied our search for a co-op game to play with friends that does not get old.   P.S.  I found it to be reminscent of FTL, another game that I love. The resource management and the way that you control power to the rooms.

Fun and creative game involving resouce management, as well as learning how to sacrifice rooms, delay your own destruction, and when to run and when to advance. It has a surprising amount of strategy to it. PAUSE the game, and make your moves, and cross your fingers, then unpause the game and holy ♥♥♥♥. Once you get the hang of it (the learning curve isn't too steep), and once you get further and further into the game, you get the feeling that everything is just stacked against you more and more. It's awesome. The sense of threat and stress becomes constant, after a time. It takes skill to keep going. Love this game and I highly recommend it if you like the idea of resource management, rogue-like -ish, and randomly generated levels.
Solid gameplay, good replayability. The difficulty curve can be tough, but that's typical of rouge-likes.
Solid gameplay, good replayability. The difficulty curve can be tough, but that's typical of rouge-likes.

For a quick and simple fun game with awesome: * pixel art * colors * rpg elements * tower defense elements * interesting back story  I loved dungeon of the endless. It can really be endless if you try to get all the achievements, but in this special case, trying to get them doesn't feel like a job, but an opportunity to get even more from such a simple, but beautiful game.
Great art, sound effects and characters. With many ships/game-modes to unlock and new challenges to attempt, this game has a lot of replayability.
Great blend of several different styles of game, with all the random replayability of a roguelike. Reinstalling for the third time and realized I never gave it the ol' thumbs up.

This is such an awesome game! I have played this game soo much, but offline so thats why I have 4 hours on this. But this is an awesome game which you should 100% play, this has to be one of the best games I have ever played. For the reason I had been playing offline is because the game can be eaisly used with a touch pad and keyboard. So you can play it out and about. Yeah I love that game I actually bring a laptop around to play it.
A really great and unique game, love every aspect of it.
Really fun if you have a couple of friends to play with

This game is more so a strategy game than anything else, it does have RPG elements like obtaining and equiping equipment and leveling up, but this game has a somewhat high learning curve so the average player may struggle on their first ten attempts even on the easiest setting. It also can become a little RNG based on certain difficulties / floors within the game which can mean the difference between a successful clear and a horrible defeat. Overall the game is pretty decent and outright entertaining even if you play alone.
